original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week has flown by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, I'm getting increasingly excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3 00am last night watching movies with Bethany. There has been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown  last night, we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teenager should see. It was better than I expected. Then, we watched Gigli, yeah, it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer television used to be a barren landscape of reruns, but now there are two exceptional new shows that have captivated my attention. I've been watching both obsessively for the past week. One show stands out for its audacious concept, despite having no apparent LGBTQ+ representation. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin aims to expand his successful West Hollywood salon to Beverly Hills, but it's his bombastic declaration that caught my attention. While flipping through channels, I stumbled upon Jonathan, looking equally self-absorbed and uninspired, standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive, proclaiming in a public voice, 'I'm going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world!' I was hooked. Not since Rocco have I found a character so infuriatingly fascinating to watch.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week has been a challenging one for me. My right shoulder has been plagued by tendonitis, situated right under my shoulder blade. As a result, when I move my arm excessively, especially when using a mouse on a computer, it becomes excruciating. I've been on a marathon of updating my website and working on other online tasks, which has left me with little strength to lift a pencil. The lack of sleep has only added to my discomfort. I'm not feeling particularly well at the moment, but I'm hoping to improve soon. My mom's surgery went smoothly, and her eyesight has shown some improvement. She can now make out fuzzy shapes and distinguish basic colors. Although she still struggles with her vision, I'm optimistic that she'll regain her sight fully soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished: I had a remarkable experience doing laundry with the kids today. As I navigated the process, I was struck by how quickly even the simplest tasks can become a daunting ordeal. I also discovered that strangers can be incredibly kind and sweet, often simply because they feel like being kind. I didn't feel like they were trying to gain something from me; it was a genuine act of kindness. To make matters worse, I was covered in kid's drool and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit. Additionally, I'm not sure I'll ever be able to bathe again, so there wasn't even an olfactory incentive there! As I'm doing two things at the moment, I'm composing this post and watching a collection of videos. I'm accomplishing both tasks from the comfort of my room, seated at my desk.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It's 11 14 pm MST, and I'm currently sitting in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of my job's personnel director. While I don't mind doing it, I often find myself wondering when the line is crossed from being helpful to being taken advantage of. I'm grateful to be able to use my skills to assist others, but I've been staying up late reading lately, so I was looking forward to an early night, until I realized it would be more practical to get the computer back to its owner. No rest for the weary, indeed! As I finished the task, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation in the 'Is This a Date?' saga, so, after the unusual lunch, my confidence wavered, I forgot to share an important piece of the story. Before Pat shows up to lunch, Dustin starts talking about what a nice guy Pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding, realizing that we're discussing more about finding Dustin's best friend a girl than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and then silently asked myself  Am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what happens now?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I would like everyone to take a moment to think before acting. I'd like each and every individual in the world to take a moment to reflect before getting out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to think critically throughout the day. If they're not prepared to do so, I'd like it if they would simply go back to bed and rest. I'm frustrated with the lack of thoughtful decision-making. I'm not the most intelligent person, but I'm not referring to complex, intellectually demanding issues. I believe it's reasonable to hold people accountable for their thoughtless actions. Let's focus on a few specific examples today, and we'll save more complex issues for another time, sound good?

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished: Two issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post  1. True, the Bush administration's stimulus efforts are stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Robert Rubin, in a recent interview on NPR's Marketplace, stated that the same stimulus effect could have been achieved without the long-term debt hangover by implementing different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low- and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin, whose name is music to our ears. Quickly, can you name a Bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with Rubin's gravitas? Still thinking... it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the Republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. Came home at like quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet.. Got there a little late but it's all good, i did my full on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault and third on beam, 29.45 all around which isn't bad bc my meets get better as the season goes on..
polished: 'She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun,' says The Offspring. It's been a while since they've updated, but there's not much to say. We went to the cove to see Supernothing, and they were great as usual. I got to chill with Tiago. Saturday. I went to work, then out with Joe and Rach, met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. I came home around quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet. I arrived a bit late, but it's all good - I did my full-on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault, and third on beam, with a score of 29.45, which isn't bad because my meets get better as the season goes on.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? Like when you're sitting in math class, feeling bored out of your skull, and wondering what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? And then you realize that you exist and you're in math class, and you wonder why. Suddenly, it hits you  the fact that you're going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Have you ever had that happen? I hate that. You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? Anyone can see that sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is cruel and an unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: I've come to the realization that my monopoly phase has run its course, and I'm vowing to never lay my hands on that iron again - not the hot one, but the game piece. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the Farqu game, possibly because I let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Regardless of how the story goes, it can't compare to this Texas-sized headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve and must say they're doing the trick; all I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation. Your phone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... at the drive-in.

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Well, today has been a long day. We drove home from Indiana. I suppose I'll have to be selective about what I write about, as I could easily take up a significant amount of time and space, and I'm just not feeling energetic enough. First, I must say that camp was truly awesome and even better than I could have expected. God has been doing so much in my life lately, and it's just amazing. I've sort of turned over a new leaf, but I'm back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. Most of what we did was visit the fair, attend church, watch a parade, go to Walmart, and watch movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: Today is my last day of summer vacation! I'm excited but also a bit anxious, as I have a dentist appointment at 9 am. I'd rather get it over with now rather than trying to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely feeling nervous, scared, and jittery about the thought of it. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling at everything I do. However, starting new things can be challenging. I dislike being a pawn and not knowing what's going on, as I told Cassie, 'I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight.' This is going to be a whole new ball game for me.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how, as early as 1996, the then-governor of Uttar Pradesh warned about the looming threat of a 'third Islamic state' emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and current governor of Uttar Pradesh, had previously predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times. Shourie raises a pertinent question when he asks, does the fact that T.V. Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, penned these warnings make them more credible? Or do you conclude that Rajeswar's consistent warnings suggest he is a closet communalist and unfit to continue as governor of Uttar Pradesh?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished: Attitude  indifferent, mood  bored. I'm looking forward to tonight after a long, hard day in the trenches. I barely had any time to write anything for you readers, but I'm glad to see Tigger taking over the reins and making an appearance. She's talking about things, and I don't have much to say about them. Yesterday, I attended a production of Shakespeare on the green, which was a lovely play, but I had to leave before the closing curtain, which was a bit disappointing. However, I hope to see the entire play someday. I digress. Akcron is correct about the problems with the shower - it's just that it's hard not to laugh at myself in the shower, and the looks people get when they're committing self-torture can be quite entertaining.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: For the past two days, I've been overwhelmed with debilitating exhaustion, feeling utterly drained. Last evening, I went home and collapsed into a deep sleep, only rousing myself when my mother called me around 8 30 PM. Upon waking, I found myself in a darkened room, struggling to discern the time or date. For a few disoriented seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and my futile attempts to grasp reality. I find myself wondering why I'm feeling so fatigued... The weather outside is quite pleasant today, with a gentle drizzle falling from the sky. Although, I'm told it's been raining nonstop for the past three days in Calcutta.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was a disappointing evening. I had to abandon the sweater I was knitting, as I had only about 14 inches completed. Unfortunately, I lost around $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 per skein), as it had developed too many stitches by the time I reached the armholes and the mohair was knotting itself together as I knitted, making frogging (ripping out rows) ineffective. The yarn broke a significant amount. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I simply ripped it apart and spent the evening watching season two of Sex and the City (a great way to unwind, actually!). Eventually, I grew tired of it and discarded the project. I suppose I did learn a thing or two from the experience.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading for the week, specifically Edward S. Casey's "Getting Back into Place  Toward a Renewed Sense of the World". The first chapter, "Implacement", and the second, "Displacement", caught my attention. In the first chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force  we're running out of time, we've saved time, and we're just in time. He makes the case that using place as the center of culture provides a more grounded community. So far, this book is the first reading that has truly captivated me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: Whatever they put into freeze pops to create their vibrant colors, there must be some sort of warning  it may make your life a bit surreal. And while giggling is enjoyable, one wonders if we would have found ourselves stumbling upon that fire escape, drinking beer in the fierce wind, had we not been snacking on them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to flip through an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the mail. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have anticipated that within these pages were the special deals of a lifetime? Not I, for certain. I'll list a few  buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever-arch files, get a barbecue.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: I'm currently listening to 'The Little Drummer Boy' by Stevan Pasero. Meanwhile, I have a post about the recent 39-hour Senate session, where Republicans dominated the judicial nominations. I must admit, I didn't watch the entire ordeal, but I did tune in a couple of times. The entire exercise was a colossal waste of time, orchestrated by Republicans who were upset that Democrats wouldn't rubber-stamp four of President Bush's controversial judicial nominees, allowing them to score political points by prolonging the process. It's worth noting that Democrats have already confirmed 168 of Bush's judicial nominees, but that wasn't good enough for the power-hungry Republicans, who seem to believe they have a mandate for this kind of political grandstanding.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This weekend was a good one. After a long time, I spent a lot of time outdoors, indulging in some much-needed greenery. Additionally, I made time to listen to a lot of music, something I should have started doing sooner. I also read a lot, finishing three books over the weekend  Bruce Sterling's 'Heavy Weather', Larry Niven's 'World of Ptavvs', and Octavia Butler's 'Parable of the Sower'. 'Heavy Weather' was a thrilling cyberpunk romp through a near-future USA, ravaged by global warming and anarchy. While it was cleverly written, well-paced, and altogether very convincing, I must admit that I didn't come away with any truly profound insights about the story or characters. Not that they aren't well-crafted and vividly portrayed - it's a good book, but not a great one, in my opinion.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: The aftermath of the first week back from practicum was a struggle, but it wasn't until the second week that the smoke began to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was struck, but the eventual meeting with the course coordinator allowed me to release my burden, and in doing so, I prevented another student from being stuck with a pedagogically deficient practicum experience. Yesterday, on Monday, I ran into another agitated classmate who was determined to warn the student who was about to embark on the next practicum, and I calmed her down, suggesting that we should first approach the administrator.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: Well, things have been incredibly busy around here, but there's always time for stress-relieving activities. I've found that I'm not exactly a pro at 8-ball and ping pong! Rick, also known as the Canuck, consistently beats me in regular matches - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always available for a quick game. Last night, I participated in an 8-ball tournament at the hot spot, our recreation tent, which is equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and, of course, the ever-present ping pong table. I was doing quite well throughout my one entire game until I scratched on the eight ball, unfortunately. Despite that, I still had a great time - the most enjoyable part was when two Dutch soldiers joined the tournament.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: Fall 1974  I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to push through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. As I'm not a math person, I hate math; I'm math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to answer it. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and, just as I was finding a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and, once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday to Thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade-level team, which are the things I need to consider as I spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had I known I was going to move prior to the end of my school year, I would have discarded much of the books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate, Jill, for helping with all of this. She was still teaching this month in my old room, so she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me.

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished: You can't help but feel it, you can't escape it  a piece of you will always remain with me. Even if I never bore you a child, even if I was never married to you, even if I was never officially bound to you... I loved you immensely, and to this day, the feeling still resonates within my heart. Forever, I will always be reminded of the few precious nights we spent together, our hearts and limbs intertwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach... or a kiss under the rain. Whenever I feel the sensation of a dark glass piercing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... the eternal love that once resided within me... and still lingers. For her.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I'm uncomfortable with investigative reporting. The concept seems quite unsettling to me. Or, I'll rephrase it - the article I'm working on and its consequences aren't exactly something I'm comfortable with. Perhaps it's because I don't believe in it strongly enough, so I can't quite grasp the full extent of it. The underlying passion behind it. The full-fledged commitment towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you're not encouraged to ask questions. In fact, you're often discouraged from doing so. They can even put you in jail for asking questions, citing internal security measures. I'm not accustomed to this freedom of speech, nor am I used to speaking out loud. I'm not the most natural person to voice my opinions freely.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We ventured to Guintubdan, La Carlota, a destination many of us had never visited before. The trek to the falls was a 30-minute walk, and we were all panting by the end of it. Whew! But we persevered and made it to the falls. The water was icy cold, and the chill was palpable, making our bodies feel numb. We stayed for less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls, which required another 30-minute trek. Despite the challenges, the trip was well worth it, as the falls were calming and the scenery was breathtaking. It was as if we could hear ourselves harmonizing with nature. Soaking in the cold water felt like a form of communion with Mother Earth. The combination of cold air and water was almost soporific, making us feel lulled to sleep.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. There is nothing better then to see the excitement on your childs face. After egg hunting, we all went to church. Even though the 'easter bunny' is fun and all. We do make sure our kids know the true meaning of the holidays. This was megan's first easter, she looked so cute dressed in her jean dress and stockings :)
polished: On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, expecting the Easter egg hunt to begin at 11 a.m. However, it turned out that it was scheduled for the previous day, Friday. Thankfully, I had brought a bag of eggs with us, just in case. Connor had a great time searching for eggs in the park. On Sunday morning, when he woke up, he was thrilled that the Easter bunny had visited. There's nothing quite like seeing the excitement on a child's face. After egg hunting, we attended church, even though the Easter bunny is a fun and festive part of the holiday. We make sure our kids understand the true meaning behind the holidays. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her jean dress and stockings.

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished: I previously expressed my support for my parents, almost to the point of taking their side. However, I've had a change of heart. Parents often think they know us too well, to the point where they can read our emotions from our facial expressions. But they don't truly know us. And when I go upstairs after arguing with Nicole about Kelli, as I just did a few minutes ago, and they ask me to tell them what's wrong. Yes, how about you let me handle it? I don't need to constantly explain what's bothering me. Here's the situation with Nicole and Kelli. Kelli and Nicole don't get along. At all.

original: My heinous mood has passed. Forthcoming period + forgetting to take prozac until late in the day = very sad, prone to tears kristin. But surprise of boyfriend at my doorstep + ice cream sundae + holding boyfriend's hand after i had a terribly scary dream in which people started shooting machine guns at the news bureau = kristin feeling better. And i don't have to work this morning la la la la la but i do have to call a man at kmiz to get his rate card. polished: My mood has lifted. Forthcoming days ahead, I plan to take Prozac until late tonight, feeling very sad and prone to tears. But a lovely surprise at my doorstep - an ice cream sundae, and holding my boyfriend's hand - made my day better. After having a terribly scary dream, in which people started shooting machine guns at the news bureau, I felt better. I don't have to work this morning, but I do have to call a man at KMiZ to get his rate card. Tonight, I get to see two of my best friends, Amy and Kate, hopefully with time to study in between. And tomorrow, maybe I will see someone I haven't seen for quite a while for our WW date.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished: At a recent naturalization ceremony in Jacksonville, a unique scene unfolded. A crowd of nearly 200 people gathered to welcome the newest Americans, but just before they left, an immigration official made an unusual request. The official, directing the swearing-in, urged the new citizens to stop by a voter registration table, where a group of Republican volunteers were waiting to distribute forms. The volunteers had checked the party affiliation box ahead of time, ensuring that all the new voters would be registered as Republicans. The unusual scene was witnessed by Linda Cross, who was there to support her husband, Dario Cruz, as he took his citizenship oath.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I've always taken great pride in making every guest at Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible. I strive to ensure they feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday, I'm proud to say I succeeded. The masses gathered on Perry Avenue, where many consider it an extreme privilege, at 4 30 pm. My best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a massive pan of baked ziti, and the tables were set with all the food I had prepared. The bells were ringing loudly. Before I could even blink, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, and that brought a huge smile to my face. I missed that guy so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along; she's expecting, and this is the closest I could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I have been hesitant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, as a non-American blogger. However, since I started it, I suppose I'd better say something. Firstly, I think the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely misguided. The moment you accord automatic reverence and protection to any symbol, you've taken a small but significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle - they don't inherently represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: I recently watched Troy with my family and was not particularly impressed. While I won't go into specifics, I do think it had potential. However, I believe too much energy was devoted to the set, which was magnificent, and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, and so on. The retelling of the story was not particularly engaging, and I don't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was somewhat weak. Additionally, I thought the score was poor, and it was essentially a copy of Gladiator, which used the background music of a wailing woman to great effect because it added depth and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Introducing the newest atom/rss reader on the block  Urllink's Pulpfiction 1.0, a freshly squeezed software from Urllink. This app offers native app-like features. Please note that it's not free, as it's a paid service. You can try it for 15 days, or upgrade to a premium version for $25. One notable feature is that each post is an independent entity, allowing for easy organization, storage, labeling, and deletion. This could be a game-changer for news tracker enthusiasts. The app imports and exports opml, as expected.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her around, annoying me (just joking...). Even though she was only here for a week, she really made her presence felt, and I mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of a time not so long ago - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that I won't see her for quite a while - with her going to Bristol in September/October and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how I miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: And there's nothing inherently wrong with PCs – if I were a full-bore gamer with the time to do so, I'd certainly have a PC system for the wealth of available games. However, except for a few unique products, the huge wall of games at CompuSA starts getting repetitive after a while – at first I'm envious, then I start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, and simulations. There are so many variations of Age of Empires that it becomes comical. Aoe – with orcs! Aoe – with spaceships! Aoe – with fuzzy wombats! It's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line  'In a world...'

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished: The chief operating officer of PX Market, John Yurkanin, sent an email on Monday, December 11, 2000, to all market participants. The email was regarding the loss of continuity in the PX day-ahead auction due to ISO rule changes, which resulted in the emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday. This has had a negative effect on the PX day-ahead auction market. The combination of soft and hard caps has resulted in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all participants, and will probably not provide the ISO with the sought-after reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the ISO offers. PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished: Mark Guzman, 6-28-02.nsf, just wanted to confirm that you received this message from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette. -Bill, beginning immediately, Enron has purchased control of the area, including reserves and services from BPA. The company allows services to sell unit contingent energy as an hourly firm, since BPA is supplying reserves for up to 60 minutes. If Grays Harbor Paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage, RT should notify BPA dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example, if Grays unit trips as 1333 RT would notify BPA and sink that across the top of the hour for 1400, the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time BPA will carry the schedule.

original: Cstclai.nsf ---------------------- forwarded by carol st clair/hou/ect on 05/05/2000 04:11 pm --------------------------- carol st clair 04/26/2000 04:41 pm to: rod nelson/hou/ect@ect cc: subject: deutsche bank rod: here are their credit issues: 1. In the cross-default language that want to add language that basically says that even if a cross-default occurs, unless the non-defaulting determines in good faith that performance by the defaulting party of its obligations under the master is "endangered", then no cross default is triggered. 2. In credit event upon merger we had commented that instaed of the "materially weaker" standard we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below bbb- by s&p. Do you feel strongly about this?
polished:
Here are their credit issues 

1. In the event of a cross-default, unless the non-defaulting party determines in good faith that the defaulting party's performance is "endangered", then no cross-default is triggered.

2. In the event of a credit event upon merger, we had commented that instead of the "materially weaker" standard, we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below BBB- by S&P. Do you feel strongly about this?

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished: The El Paso pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that need to be addressed to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the California border. El Paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in California. In a January 3 letter to the pipeline, Daniel M. Adamson, Director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the California gas market.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished: Mahatma Gandhi's conception of ahimsa, or non-violence, was a concept that went on to mature over time. As I became more vigilant about my thoughts and words, the lines in the anthem "As you sow, so shall you reap" began to resonate with me. The story of my experiments with truth, as told in my autobiography, is a testament to the power of ahimsa. Today, October 2, is the day Mahatma Gandhi was born in the year 1869. Despite being born over two centuries ago, his life and message remain relevant to our lives today.

original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished: The Senate and House of Representatives have reached an informal agreement over the weekend, with Senate Majority Leader Charles Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi making an informal pact. Under this agreement, the Senate Majority Leader has agreed to sponsor the Social and Community Development (Socal) bill. Polanco, a Democrat, is currently embroiled in a personal scandal and his political career is reportedly on life support. As a result, it is reported that his political career is essentially over. Polanco is planning to run for Mayor of Los Angeles instead of seeking another Senate term. The bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, either today or tomorrow. The bill will first go to the Senate Energy Committee. Senator Brian Schatz, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the MOU, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a social bankruptcy increases.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
NOTICE TO ALL NYMEX AND COMEX MEMBERS

FROM  Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President

DATE  October 3, 2000

RE  Notice of CFTC Approval of New NYMEX Rule 6.40c  ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants")

Please be advised that the CFTC has approved new NYMEX Rule 6.40c ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect.

New NYMEX Rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent CFTC "advisory," permits FCMS, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("AP") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.

original: Kwatson (non-privileged).pst hello kim, my name is joelene whittaker and i am a recruiter with stm associates. Dte energy, www.dtecs.com/sitemap.html, has retained us to assist them in placing two director of sales for eastern and western regions. The eastern position will be located in ann arbor, michigan and the western position in denver, colorado. Both director of sales will report to the vice president of sales. Qualifications of this position include a minimum of 5 years of sales experience and an additional minimum of 2 years experience with a trading company is preferred. polished: I am Joelene Whittaker, a recruiter with STM Associates, and I am excited to announce that we are seeking two Directors of Sales for our Eastern and Western regions. The Eastern position will be based in Ann Arbor, Michigan, while the Western position will be located in Denver, Colorado. Both Directors of Sales will report directly to the Vice President of Sales. A strong understanding of the U.S. coal, transportation, and electric utility industries, including coal tolling, marketing, and origination functions used to support coal trading operations is also required. If you are interested in this opportunity, please submit your resume and a cover letter to [insert contact information]. We look forward to reviewing your application.

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished: As of this week, Enrononline has started offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. In determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online, I review the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and I also examine any board resolutions we may have received when we executed the master agreement. What I am finding is that in the past, when we requested resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions, the resolutions often did not allow the counterparties to enter into currency transactions. Given that transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us, I wanted us to be mindful to review these old resolutions and not solely rely on the "restrictions" contained in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
I would be delighted to generate the form of a transaction agreement; however, I have a number of questions. 

1. Can you clarify the relationship between the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the northwest pipeline? Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by EWEB? 

2. What volume is being sold each day? You use the term DCQ and you also discuss a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally, there would be no tolerance with a DCQ transaction.

3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction? Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: The spreadsheet below provides the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule DR). The rate schedule effective from August 2000 through September 2000 yields a significantly larger commodity charge, as SDG&E customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from SDG&E over those two months. SDG&E customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cents and the implicit commodity average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cents. The average implicit commodity from June 2000 through December 2001 is 6.9 cents for deliveries starting September 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cents.

original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished: Here is a rundown of events from last week  we executed a commitment letter with J.P. Morgan and Salomon Smith Barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our Northern Natural Gas Company and Transwestern Pipeline Company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity.

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished: I am attaching the final order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in potential refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but PGE was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with January 01 and promises further orders regarding December 00 and benchmark prices through April 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16,000). With respect to sales to California, we have concluded at least one short-term sale and have talked with Cal Dept of Water Resources about longer-term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last I heard.
