And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.
polished: Shah Rukh Khan  courage, determination, and a single-minded vision - these are the qualities shared by the biggest achievers. These are the brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What appears insurmountable to us, becomes an irresistible stage to our next speaker, who was born to perform on it. Let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma  Imagine a two-and-a-half-year-old, riding on a moped behind her mother, in the scorching Rajasthan heat, on a hot summer afternoon, without knowing their destination. Just 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. That technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before i talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3." we already saw that briefly yesterday. And what you can see is — it is actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.
polished: I'm going to discuss a technology we're developing at Oxford that we believe has the potential to revolutionize the way computer games and Hollywood movies are produced. This technology simulates humans, featuring simulated bodies and simulated nervous systems to control those bodies. Before I elaborate further on this technology, let's take a brief look at the current state of human characters in computer games. This is a clip from a game called 'Grand Theft Auto 3,' which we previewed yesterday. As you can see, it's an exceptionally good game, ranking among the most successful of all time.

original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished: Just like many people around the world, my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup held in France this summer. We spent hours watching the incredible athletes, marveling at the goals and the clean, engaging gameplay, and simultaneously, we couldn't help but notice that outside the field, the conversation was centered around equal pay and the stark contrast between countries that do and don't compensate their athletes. Our shared obsession with the tournament led us to decide that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US would be the best place for us to watch the games live. However, it wasn't until a few matches into the tournament that a friend pointed out to me, 'Why does it seem like every commercial I'm seeing is for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?'

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: I'd like to share with you the fascinating story of the future of money. Let's begin by exploring the culture of the Yap, a society that thrived in Micronesia during the early 1900s. The Yap, with their unique form of currency, use limestone discs called Rai stones. Unlike our coins, these Rai stones are not exchanged or moved around, as they can become quite massive. The largest Rai stone is approximately four tons and 12 feet across. To keep track of ownership, the Yap simply keep a record of who possesses a portion of the stone. There's a remarkable story about a group of sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered some difficulties, and the stone ended up falling into the sea.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: You've been accused of a crime you didn't commit, and it's impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist on maintaining your innocence, you'll likely be found guilty and executed. However, if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you'll be set free. This was the daunting choice facing those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of a mix of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that prioritized repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by the Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem, marked by frequent battles with their Native American neighbors and rival groups of French settlers.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: There are hundreds of thousands of people on transplant waiting lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren't nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That's the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We're not yet able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange, are already within our grasp. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object, one slice at a time.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon, I'm thrilled to be speaking here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'll be discussing a phenomenon that is changing the world, and its name is people power. I'll begin with an anecdote, reminiscent of a Monty Python-style sketch. It's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet  you'll gaze into a crystal ball and see the future, which will be accurate. But you must share it with the world. Okay, curiosity gets the better of you, and you take the bet, gazing into the crystal ball. An hour later, you're sitting in a prominent TV studio, on a top show, and you share the story.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished: We're about to embark on a journey in 1964, when Bob Dylan, at the tender age of 23, is at the pinnacle of his career. Dubbed the voice of a generation, he's churning out timeless classics at an astonishing rate, but a small minority of critics argue that Bob Dylan is borrowing from others. Fast-forward to 2004, Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes the Beatles' "White Album" and combines it with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." This unexpected mashup becomes an instant online sensation, prompting the Beatles' record company to send out numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Interestingly, "The Grey Album" is now considered a remix.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: Well, that's an obvious observation, indeed. I began exploring this concept about 12 years ago, in the context of developing countries. As you gaze at a world map, you'll notice that every country has areas where good teachers are scarce. I started working on this issue in 1999 with a simple experiment in New Delhi, aiming to address the ironic problem of good teachers avoiding the places where they're needed most.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished: Currently, the majority of refugees reside in urban areas rather than refugee camps. We account for over 60% of the global refugee population. As the majority of refugees live in cities, there is a pressing need for a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Rather than investing in the construction of walls, it would be more effective to allocate resources to programs that empower refugees to help themselves. We always have to leave behind our material possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If given the opportunity to lead a productive life, refugees can not only help themselves but also contribute to the development of their host country. I was born in Bukavu, a city in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as the fifth of 12 children in a family.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished: I have two questions for you. One  whose shoulders do you stand on? And two  what do you stand for? These are two questions I always begin my poetry workshops with students, as poetry can sometimes seem like a dead art form, often associated with older white men who seem destined to be so, like Benjamin Button or something. I ask my students these two questions, and then I share how I answer them, which is in these three sentences that I repeat as a mantra before every performance  I am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. In fact, I was doing it in the corner over there, making faces.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished: I didn't always make my living from music. For about five years after graduating from an esteemed liberal arts university, this was my day job. I was a self-employed living statue, affectionately known as the eight-foot bride, and I loved telling people I did this for a job because everyone always wanted to know who these freaks in real life were. Hello. One day, I painted myself white, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, I handed them a flower – and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, I threw in a gesture of sadness and longing – as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world witnessed a historic moment of awe and trepidation as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, into space. This small, two-foot-diameter metal sphere sparked a space race between the United States and the Soviet Union that would last for eighteen years and profoundly alter the world as we know it. Although Sputnik was not the first human-made object to enter space, that distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, developed by Germany during World War II for missile attacks on Allied cities. While the V-2 rocket was not particularly effective, the end of the war saw both the United States and the Soviet Union capture the technology and the scientists behind it, subsequently incorporating it into their own projects.

original: I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an ipod — an ipod that contains wagner and mozart, pop diva christina aguilera, country singer josh turner, gangsta rap artist kirk franklin, concerti, symphonies and more and more. I'm a voracious reader, a reader who deals with ian mcewan down to stephanie meyer. I have read the twilight tetralogy. And one who lives for my home theater, a home theater where i devour dvds, video on demand and a lot of television. For me, "law & order: svu," tina fey and "30 rock" and "judge judy" — "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.
polished: I'm a cultural omnivore, whose daily commute is facilitated by my attachment to an iPod, which plays a diverse range of music, from Wagner and Mozart to pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin, concerti, symphonies, and more. As a voracious reader, I've devoured the works of Ian McEwan and Stephanie Meyer, including the Twilight tetralogy. I'm also passionate about my home theater, where I indulge in DVDs, video-on-demand, and a wide variety of television shows. For me, 'Law & Order  SVU', Tina Fey's '30 Rock', and 'Judge Judy' are must-watches – the people are real, the cases are real, and the rulings are final.

original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors and people everywhere. So i'm pleased you are launching ted countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.
polished: Citizens of the world, we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale. I'm pleased to bring you a message from António Guterres, the Secretary-General of the United Nations. The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are falling behind. There is a growing tide of impatience, particularly among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all  governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals everywhere. I'm pleased to see that you're launching the TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate the momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation  a natural biological process, shrouded in centuries of stigma, is often whispered about. But why? As I speak to you now, over 800 million women worldwide are experiencing it. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to discuss openly. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can attest that it's exhausting. It's exhausting to carefully extract a discreet tampon from a brown paper bag, tucking it into your pocket during a class, and rushing to the washroom, all while attempting to appear normal. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be completely unaffected, while internally struggling with intense period cramps.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical ecosystems, they clean air, they clean water, they sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a huge diversity of species.
polished: The world's largest and most significant environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, Canada's boreal forest. Spanning across northern Canada, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world  the George River caribou herd, comprising approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, during my visit, I was unable to find one of them, but I have the antlers as proof. Throughout the boreal forest, we're fortunate to be blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They play a crucial role in cleaning the air, water, and sequestering large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a vast diversity of species.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.
polished: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, comprising fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers roamed this celestial realm, having no family other than each other - they didn't even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, stood out from the others. His skin was covered in painful scars, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit, Yaya, was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck into Yaya's house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. Essentially, what the company was doing was creating a medical device where you would be able to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. So this was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also, it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.
polished: So, I graduated seven years ago from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. I attended a career fair on campus, where I landed an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there wasn't much information available about the company, but the little that was there was quite impressive. Essentially, Theranos was creating a medical device that would enable you to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. This would eliminate the need for a large needle in your arm to obtain your blood test results. This was intriguing not only because it was less painful, but also because it had the potential to revolutionize diagnostic testing.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to become a polar specialist, specializing in the polar regions, began when I was just four years old, when my family relocated from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, Greenland. We settled in a tiny Inuit community of 200 people, where we were one of only three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn't have a television, nor computers, nor radio. We didn't even have a telephone. My days were spent entirely outside with the Inuit, playing. The snow and ice were my playground, and the Inuit were my mentors. It was there that I became truly captivated by this polar realm.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.

polished: I'd like to take you on an epic quest aboard the Rosetta spacecraft. For the past two years, it has been my passion to escort and land the probe on a comet. To do so, I'd like to share with you the origin of our solar system. Approximately 4.5 billion years ago, a cloud of gas and dust existed. At the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Simultaneously, the planets, comets, and asteroids we know today took shape. According to theory, when the Earth had cooled slightly after its formation, comets massively impacted our planet, delivering water to Earth. They likely also brought complex organic material to our planet, which may have jump-started the emergence of life.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, President Theodore Roosevelt embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. He slept among towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and spent hours conversing around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt was an avid outdoorsman, but Muir had invited him to Yosemite for more than just camping  the valley was in danger. Although Yosemite had been protected land since 1864, it was still at risk of overdevelopment in 1903. The battle to set aside land for both preservation and public use had been ongoing for decades, a challenge that proved easier said than done. The struggle began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners flooded westward, seeking gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: Hello. This is my first trip outside the walls of Gaza, and I'm thrilled to be here. Gaza is a challenging place, with all borders closed on every side, making it one of the most restrictive environments in the world. Despite these limitations, I find solace in gazing up at the sky. On some days, we're lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make do with fires on the front or on the roof of our homes.

polished: I'm sorry, but I cannot show you my face, as it would put me in danger if I were to do so. My journey began 14 years ago, when I was a young reporter fresh out of college. I landed a scoop that was quite straightforward  police officers were taking bribes from street hawkers. As a young journalist, I believed that there must be a better way to expose this corruption, as everyone knew it was happening, yet nothing was being done to stop it. So, I decided to go undercover, posing as a street vendor myself. By doing so, I was able to gather concrete evidence. The impact was immense – it was fantastic. This is what many call immersion journalism or undercover reporting.

original: One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease.eating chocolate reduces stress in students.new drug prolongs lives of patients with rare disease.health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposite claims from each other. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines?the best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We’ve come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines.keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios.
polished: One simple vitamin can significantly reduce the risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate, on the other hand, has been shown to reduce stress in students. A new drug has been found to prolong the lives of patients with a rare disease. Health headlines like these are published daily, often making seemingly opposite claims from one another. There can be a disconnect between the broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often incremental results of the medical research they cover. To avoid being misled by grabby headlines, it's essential to look at the original research they report on. We've developed a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines. Keep an eye out for the explanation provided in the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. These scenarios are designed to be simplified for better understanding.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: So, when I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my younger siblings from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "What day should we celebrate for their birthday?" I thought, "The day they were born, obviously?" It was a ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "Well, Kristen, neither of your younger brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we determine their birthdate?" Mind blown. Now, 20 years later, I'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, I try to tackle this problem globally. So, what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? That's the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the Experience Machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life, guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch  you would have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'd hardly know the difference. Your experiences would be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs would be replaced with an endless series of ups, and sounds like a rather enticing prospect.

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: I'd like to share with you the most embarrassing moment that has occurred during my years as a palliative care physician. It happened a couple of years ago. During our consultation, she inquired about whether medical marijuana might alleviate her symptoms. I reflected on everything I had learned in medical school, which didn't take long because I had learned absolutely nothing about medical marijuana.

As a firefighter, my team and I are tasked with saving lives and property from disasters such as car wrecks, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. It became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not a one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you've made a difference and everything is okay.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon plays a crucial role in a natural cycle, present in all living things  in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living organisms die, much of their stored carbon is released back to the atmosphere, where it is absorbed by new plants and other organisms. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock, while some becomes fossil fuels  coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions also release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Furthermore, human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release a significant amount of prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release approximately 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even nature's most reviled creatures harbor important secrets, but who wouldn't want to avoid a swarm of cockroaches approaching? One of the most significant differences between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Notably, cockroaches can self-stabilize when running over rough terrain. When we attached a jet pack to them or subjected them to a perturbation like an earthquake, we found that their exquisitely tuned legs enable them to self-stabilize without engaging their brainpower. They can traverse complex terrain like grass effortlessly, without becoming destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, due to their shape, they naturally roll onto their side to navigate this artificial grass test. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same underlying structure. We've recently discovered a new behavior that illustrates this capability.

polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State Senator. A few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison, which ultimately changed the trajectory of my life.
